publicationStmt.publisher: Department of English, University of New Mexico

figure.figTranscr:
Blake
AN ILLUSTRATED QUARTERLY
VOLUME 18
NUMBER 1
SUMMER 1984

row.cell: David V. Erdman, ed., The Complete Poetry and Prose of William Blake, reviewed by the Santa Cruz Blake Study Group
Stephen D. Cox, “The Stranger Within Thee”: Concepts of the Self in Late Eighteenth-Century Literature, reviewed by David Worrall
Pamela Dunbar, William Blake’s Illustrations to the Poetry of Milton, reviewed by Bette Charlene Werner
W.J.T. Mitchell, ed., The Language of Images, reviewed by Stephen Leo Carr
Zachary Leader, Reading Blake’s “Songs,” reviewed by Thomas A. Vogler
James Bogan and Fred Goss, eds., Sparks of Fire: Blake in a New Age, reviewed by Jenijoy La Belle
Aquilino Sanchez Perez, Blake’s Graphic Work and the Emblematic Tradition, reviewed by Joseph S. Salemi
Jean H. Hagstrum, Sex and Sensibility: Ideal and Erotic Love from Milton to Mozart, reviewed by Alicia Ostriker
Robert N. Essick and Morton D. Paley, Robert Blair’s The Grave, Illustrated by William Blake, reviewed by Andrew Wilton
Minna Doskow, William Blake’s Jerusalem: Structure and Meaning in Poetry and Picture, reviewed by V.A. De Luca
Blake/Hegel/Derrida: A response to Nelson Hilton’s review of Blake, Hegel and Dialectic, by David Punter

div1.p: STEPHEN LEO CARR teaches at the University of Pittsburgh. He has published several articles on Blake’s graphic art, and is at work on a book that interrelates Blake’s print-making process and his strategies of literary and pictorial representation.
V.A. DE LUCA of the University of Toronto is at work on a book about Blake and the poetics of the sublime.
JENIJOY LA BELLE is an Associate Professor of Literature at the California Institute of Technology.

ALICIA OSTRIKER is the editor of Blake’s Complete Poems (Penguin) and has cogitated on Blake and sex in this journal. Her most recent book of poems is A Woman Under the Surface (Princeton). She is a Professor of English at Rutgers University.

DAVID PUNTER is Senior Lecturer in English Studies at the University of East Anglia. His writings on Blake include Blake, Hegel and Dialectic (Amsterdam, 1982) and articles in Studies in Romanticism, Literature and History and Criticism. His most recent work, “The Sign of Blake,” will be appearing in Criticism shortly.
JOSEPH S. SALEMI is on the adjunct faculty of the Humanities Department at New York University. His interest in Blake dates from a seminar with Aileen Ward in 1976.
The SANTA CRUZ BLAKE STUDY GROUP is at work on a review of contemporary Blake criticism.

THOMAS A. VOGLER is Professor of Literature at the University of California, Santa Cruz. He has recently co-edited (with Nelson Hilton) a collection of essays on Blake, Unnam’d Forms: Blake and Textuality, to be published by The University of California Press in 1985.

BETTE CHARLENE WERNER is Editor of Publications for the Healthcare Internal Audit Group and an Instructor of English at The University of Toledo. Her book on Blake’s Milton illustrations will be published by Bucknell University Press.
ANDREW WILTON is an Assistant Curator, Department of Prints and Drawings, at the British Museum. His most recent publication is Turner and the Sublime.
DAVID WORRALL teaches in Newcastle-upon-Tyne, England. His article on Blake’s star imagery, “The ‘Immortal Tent,’ ” appeared in Bulletin of Research in the Humanities.
Editors: Morris Eaves, University of New Mexico, and Morton D. Paley, University of California, Berkeley.
Bibliographer: Thomas L. Minnick, Ohio State University.
Review Editor: Nelson Hilton, University of Georgia, Athens.
Associate Editor for Great Britain: Frances A. Carey, Assistant Curator, Department of Prints and Drawings, British Museum.

Production Office: Morris Eaves, Department of English, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, Telephone 505/277-3103.
Morton D. Paley, Department of English, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720.

Managing Editor: Robin Tawney.
Editorial Assistants: Leslie Donovan, Chapel Petty, University of New Mexico.
Blake / An Illustrated Quarterly is published under the sponsorship of the Department of English, University of New Mexico.

Subscriptions are $18 for institutions, $15 for individuals. All subscriptions are by the volume (1 year, 4 issues) and begin with the summer issue. Subscription payments received after the summer issue will be applied to the 4 issues of the current volume. Foreign addresses (except Canada and Mexico) require a $3 per volume postal surcharge for surface mail, a $10 per volume surcharge for air mail delivery. U.S. currency or international money order necessary. Make checks payable to Blake / An Illustrated Quarterly. Address all subscription orders and related communications to Robin Tawney, Blake, Department of English, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131, USA.
Many back issues are available at a reduced price. Address Robin Tawney for a list of issues and prices.

Manuscripts are welcome. Send two copies, typed and documented according to the forms suggested in the MLA Style Sheet, 2nd ed., to either of the editors: Morris Eaves, Dept. of English, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM 87131; Morton D. Paley, Dept. of English, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720.

International Standard Serial Number: 0006-453x. Blake / An Illustrated Quarterly is indexed in the Modern Language Association’s International Bibliography, the Modern Humanities Research Association’s Annual Bibliography of English Language and Literature, English Languge Notes’ annual Romantic Bibliography, ART bibliographies MODERN, American Humanities Index, and the Arts and Humanities Citation Index.
